    Recent Update on Targeting c-MYC G-Quadruplexes by Small Molecules for Anticancer Therapeutics

    • Ritapa Chaudhuri
      Ritapa Chaudhuri
      School of Chemical Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Jadavpur, Kolkata 700032, India
      More by Ritapa Chaudhuri

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Guanine-rich DNA sequences have the propensity to adopt four-stranded tetrahelical G-quadruplex (G4) structures that are overrepresented in gene promoters. The structural polymorphism and physicochemical properties of these non-Watson–Crick G4 structures make them important targets for drug development. The guanine-rich nuclease hypersensitivity element III1 present in the upstream of P1 promoter of c-MYC oncogene has the ability to form an intramolecular parallel G4 structure. The G4 structure that forms transiently in the c-MYC promoter functions as a transcriptional repressor element. The c-MYC oncogene is overexpressed in a wide variety of cancers and plays a key role in cancer progression. Till now, a large number of compounds that are capable of interacting and stabilizing thec-MYC G4 have been reported. In this review, we summarize various c-MYC G4 specific molecules and discuss their effects on c-MYC gene expression in vitro and in vivo.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    c-MYC oncoprotein, known as the master regulator of genes,(1) is a multifunctional transcription factor involved in the regulation of many physiological processes such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, protein synthesis, cell adhesion, and others.(2) It was first discovered in human Burkitt’s lymphoma as a cellular homologue of the viral oncogene, v-MYC, which was isolated from an avian retrovirus.(3) Aberrant expression of the c-MYC within cells leads to many gene alterations causing tumorigenesis and sustained tumor growth. The abnormal overexpression of c-MYC is commonly observed in carcinomas of breast, colon, and cervix, as well as small-cell lung cancer, osteosarcomas, glioblastomas, and myeloid leukemia.(4) The c-MYC gene is overexpressed in up to 70% of human cancers.(5) Considering its ubiquitous role in cancer biology, the c-MYC downregulation has become an attractive strategy for cancer treatment. However, designing and developing modulators for the c-MYC are challenging. To date, no successful small molecule inhibitor of c-MYC could be developed for clinical use. The c-MYC protein lacks a definite binding site for the modulators and also has a half-life of only 20–30 min, making it difficult to design compounds that can directly interact with the c-MYC protein.(6) In this context, the G-quadruplex found in its promoter region has emerged as a potential drug target for controlling c-MYC expression. The c-MYC gene contains a nuclease hypersensitivity element III1 (NHEIII1) located at the upstream of the P1 promoter that controls about 85–90% of the transcriptional activation of the gene.(7−9) The purine-rich strand of the DNA in this region can form a special secondary structure known as the G-quadruplex (G4), which is considered as a transcriptional repressor element.(10)
    G4s are four-stranded DNA secondary structures formed from single-stranded guanine (G)-rich sequences (Figure 1). Each guanine is Hoogsteen hydrogen-bonded to the two adjacent guanines forming a square planar arrangement, called a G-tetrad. Two or more such G-tetrads stack on top of one another to form the four-stranded helical structure of the G-quadruplex. The stability of a G4 largely depends on the monovalent cations, specifically K+ and Na+, where the positively charged cations occupy the central channel of the stacked G-tetrads and neutralize the electrostatic repulsion of guanine O6 oxygens.(11) The G4 structure formed in the NHEIII1 of c-MYC promoter adopts an intramolecular parallel conformation having three G-tetrads. It forms a thermodynamically stable structure with a considerably high melting temperature. The 3′ and 5′ flanking regions of c-MYC forms a capping structure at the corresponding terminal tetrads providing a nice binding pocket for the small molecule ligands.(12,13)
    The formation of a parallel G-quadruplex structure in the proximal promoter region of the c-MYC proto-oncogene was first reported by the Simonsson et al. in 1998.(9) Hurley et al. subsequently demonstrated that the stabilization of G4 in the c-MYC promoter region by a small molecule can repress c-MYC transcription.(10) The interest in developing small molecules for promoter G-quadruplexes was accentuated when c-MYC proto-oncogene expression was successfully downregulated by a synthetic ligand TMPyP4.(14) Thus, by controlling the expression at the transcriptional level through G-quadruplex stabilization, the undruggable nature of the c-MYC protein(6) could be addressed to some extent. However, targeting a particular quadruplex with high affinity and specificity by ligands remains a challenge. Computational studies have suggested that there are 376 000 putative G4 forming sequences (PQS) existing in the human genome.(15) Sequences that match a template of d(G3+N1–7G3+N1–7G3+N1–7G3+), where N is any base, can form a putative G4 structure.(15) Apart from telomeric G4, about 43% of human genes contain at least one PQS at the nuclease hypersensitive sites of various oncogenic promoters including BCL2, k-RAS, c-KIT, VEG-f, etc.(16−19)
    The G4 structures are topologically highly polymorphic. They can be formed from one (intramolecular) or two or more (intermolecular) DNA strands which can be further categorized into parallel, antiparallel, and mixed type structures based on the orientation of the strands.(20)

    Transcriptional Regulation of c-MYC

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The transcriptional regulation of c-MYC expression is complex and involves multiple promoters (predominantly P1 and P2) and transcriptional start sites. However, 80–95% of the transcriptional activity of this gene is controlled by the nuclease hypersensitivity element III1 (NHE III1) located 142–115 bp upstream of the P1 promoter, irrespective of either of the promoters being used.(7−10) This 27 bp G-rich sequence of NHE III1, also known as Pu27, switches between transcriptionally active duplex forms, transient single-stranded DNA and silenced G4 forms (Figure 2).(21) Unlike other noncanonical DNA structures, the assembly of a G4 requires a relatively long GC-rich, single-stranded region which is propagated by transcriptionally induced negative supercoiling.(22)
    The regulation of the c-MYC transcription involves multifarious transcription factors that interact with the NHE III1 region of the promoter.(23) The major and most abundant nucleolar phosphoprotein, nucleolin, induces the formation and stabilization of parallel stranded c-MYC G4 DNA, downregulating the c-MYC expression.(24) It also suppresses the c-MYC expression by inhibiting the binding of Sp1 transcription factor to the double-stranded (ds) NHE III1 region. In contrast, single-stranded binding protein, NM23-H2,(25) previously known to function as nucleoside diphosphate (NDP) kinase,(26) is anticipated to activate the c-MYC transcription by unwinding the G4 motif. This unwinding facilitates other single-stranded DNA binding proteins, such as CNBP(27) and hnRNP K,(28,29) to bind specifically to the purine- and pyrimidine-rich single strand of the c-MYC NHE III1, respectively, and activate the endogenous c-MYC mRNA and protein expression(30) (Figure 2). Recently, Yang and co-workers have shown that a member of the DEAD-box RNA family of helicases, DDX5 helicase, unfolds the c-MYC G4 and initiates the c-MYC transcription with excellent proficiency.(31)
    Thus, the role of different transcription factors in the formation of quadruplex and transcriptional regulation suggests that the c-MYC promoter G4 acts as a silencer element.
    In this perspective, we describe the design principle of the c-MYC G4 targeting ligands for the development of anticancer therapeutics. We present an updated progress in the development of c-MYC G4 ligands, highlighting their importance in therapeutics. An overview of some early G4 binding molecules has also been discussed. We believe that this review will open up new prospects toward designing and developing efficacious small molecules and exploiting their therapeutic potential in cancer biology.

    First Generation/Classical G4 Binding Molecules

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To date, there are numerous G4 ligands, which are listed comprehensively in a database G4LDB (G4 ligands database; http://www.g4ldb.org). Molecular design of potential anticancer agents via targeting the human telomeric DNA has been an area of active research.(32) The earliest reported G4 interacting ligands are 2,6-diamido anthraquinones(33)1, TmPyP4(10,34)2, and PIPER(35,36)3 (Figure 3), which have been used as a starting point for designing multiple closely related compounds.(37,38) 2,6-Diamido anthraquinone has inspired the synthesis of acridines such as BRACO-19(39,40)4 and other tricyclics.(41−43) In 2001, a series of cationic porphyrins (TMPyP2, TMPyP3, and TMPyP4) were identified as G4 interactive agents.(44)1H NMR solution of TmPyP4 in complex with c-MYC G4 complex revealed the stacking interaction of TmPyP4 on the top of the tetrad and electrostatic interaction of the positive charges of the ligand with the negatively charged phosphate backbone.(45) It was further reported that it suppressed the transcription of the gene, both in vitro and in vivo.(14) TmPyP4 is commercially available and has been used extensively as a standard reference in biological assays. In subsequent years, similar compounds such as Se2SAP 5,(21) porphyrazines,(46) and porphyrins containing metals(47,48) were developed as G4 interacting ligands. In 2001, Hurley and co-workers demonstrated that perylene tetracarboxylic diimide (PIPER)(36) could induce the formation of G4 structure not only from c-MYC G-rich single-stranded DNA but also from the Watson–Crick base-paired GC-rich ds DNA under physiological conditions. Further modifications to improve the physicochemical properties of the perylene compounds led to the development of naphthalene diimide (NDI) derivatives.(49) Neidle and coworkers reported that a tetra-substituted NDI, BMSG-SH-3(50)6 showing high affinity for a telomeric G4 DNA was used for clinical trials. These first-in-class compounds have not only been employed for analogue synthesis but also have inspired the discovery of a range of similar compounds. In this backdrop, telomestatin,(51)7, a natural product isolated from Streptomyces anulates, has been shown to be a very potent telomerase inhibitor. Thus, telomestatin, being a macrocyclic compound, has provoked interest in molecules that appear like a half macrocycle, for example, a bisquinolinium compound like 360A 8(52) and pyridostatin(53)9. Natural product distamycin(54)10, a ds DNA binder, interacts with G4s via an alternative groove binding mode. On the other hand, anthracene linked to a polyamine has been proposed to interact by threading a side chain into the central cavity of the quadruplex structure.(46) However, research on G4-mediated gene regulation received a new thrust when quarfloxin (CX-3543), 11, developed by Cylene Pharmaceuticals, progressed to phase II clinical trials (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT00780663) due to its ability to interact with G4s in vivo(55) (Figure 3). These studies have indicated that quadruplex DNAs should be given serious consideration as important targets for the treatment of various human disorders.
    It soon has become clear that certain structural features of ligands are desirable for targeting DNA G4s. Most of the ligands have a flat, aromatic/heteroaromatic core that is believed to interact with the flat, aromatic G-tetrad of the G4 structure by hydrophobic and stacking interactions. The positively charged side chains of ligands bind to the negatively charged phosphate backbone of the quadruplex through electrostatic interactions. Generally, small molecules bind to G4s either by stacking interactions with the terminal tetrads or by electrostatic interactions with the loops and grooves. Most of the small molecules bind to the c-MYC G4 via end stacking mode.

    Biophysical Techniques for Understanding c-MYC-G4 Interactions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Biophysical techniques have widely been used to gather information about electronic structure, size, shape, dynamics, polarity, and modes of interaction of quadruplexes with other molecules.(56) X-ray crystallography(57) and NMR spectroscopy(58) are useful for determining the structure as well as studying a detailed mechanism of interactions with bound ligands. The ability of a ligand to stabilize the G4 structure can be studied by optical methods such as UV–visible, CD spectroscopy, and FRET-based melting assays. UV–vis spectroscopy is a conventional method to directly determine the binding affinity (Ka) of ligands with G4 DNA. The property of G4s to exhibit a hyperchromic shift at 295 nm upon heat denaturation is further utilized to determine the stabilization potential of ligands by measuring the change in melting temperature in the absence and presence of ligands. An increase in the melting temperature of G4 DNA in the presence of ligands is indicative of preferential binding of small molecules to the folded quadruplex. The characteristic CD signatures displayed by the G4 DNAs at 240, 260, and 295 nm are used for differentiating various quadruplex topologies (parallel, antiparallel, mixed hybrid) and conformational changes of G4s in the presence of ligands.(59,60) Like UV–vis spectroscopy, the DNA melting assay is performed using CD to determine the ability of a ligand to stabilize a quadruplex. Another powerful method for probing the stabilization potential of G4 ligands is the Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)-based melting assay.(61) In this protocol, G4 forming oligonucleotides are tagged with a donor and an acceptor fluorophore at the 3′ and 5′ ends. In a folded quadruplex structure, the two dyes are in close proximity, and the fluorescence of the donor is quenched by the acceptor fluorophore. As the quadruplex undergoes thermal denaturation, the donor and acceptor fluorophores move apart, and the gradual increase in donor emission is measured as a function of temperature. If a ligand binds and stabilizes a G4, an increase in the melting temperature (Tm) of G4 DNA is observed. The difference in the melting temperature (ΔTm) of a G4 in the presence and absence of a ligand provides an estimation of the ability of the ligand to stabilize the G4. A ligand that stabilizes a quadruplex strongly shows a high stabilization potential (ΔTm) value.
    Another efficient and rapid biophysical technique is the G4 fluorescent intercalator displacement (G4-FID) assay(62) that provides important information regarding the binding affinity and selectivity of nonfluorescent ligands toward G4 structures. In this method, a quadruplex binding fluorescent probe (like Thiazole Orange, TO) is used, which shows an enhanced fluorescence response in the presence of a G4. The displacement of TO by the ligand leads to a decrease in fluorescence intensity. This can be correlated to the binding affinity of the ligand to the G4 DNA. To determine the thermodynamic parameters of ligand/quadruplex interactions such as the change in enthalpy (ΔH), change in entropy (ΔS), binding affinity constant (Ka), and stoichiometry of the binding process, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC)(63) has been extensively used. The kinetics of the G4 ligand interactions is studied using surface plasmon resonance (SPR).(64) Microscale thermophoresis (MST) is a recently developed method for quantitative evaluation of DNA–ligand interactions.(65) It is an aptamer based binding assay that relies on the movement of small molecules in a thermal gradient to generate binding curves. For fluorescent probes, fluorescence spectroscopy can be used to determine the binding affinity of ligands for quadruplexes. The PCR stop assay(66) is performed to monitor the induction of G4 formation in specific sequences by G4 ligands. In addition to these principal methods, other techniques such as equilibrium dialysis,(67) mass spectrometry,(68) electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA),(69) dimethyl sulfate (DMS) methylation protection assays,(69) etc. are used that provide information about the ligand–quadruplex interactions. Apart from these, molecular modeling studies are now routinely used to investigate structure, dynamics, surface properties, and thermodynamics of G4/ligand interactions.(39)

    In Vitro Techniques for the Evaluation of Ligands in Cellular Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A variety of in vitro techniques are routinely employed to evaluate the effects of ligands in cellular system. The MTT assay is performed to assess the effects of ligands on cell proliferation. The MTT assay is a tetrazolium dye-based colorimetric assay that reflects the total percentage of viable cells in the presence of compounds. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) is employed to quantify c-MYC mRNA expression in cells in real time. Western Blot analysis is performed to examine the effects of ligands in c-MYC protein expression. The chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay(24) is performed to determine whether G4 ligands influence the binding of cellular transcription factors to c-MYC promoter G4 and modulate gene expression. The exon specific assay in CA46 cells (Figure 4a) is another validation of G4-mediated effects on c-MYC expression.(70) This method involves a pair of Burkitts lymphoma (RAJI/Ramos and CA46) cell lines in which oncogenic translocation occurs between an immunoglobin (IgH) heavy chain on chromosome 14 and the c-MYC promoter on chromosome 8. The translocation maintains G4-mediated control of c-MYC on both chromosomes in RAJI, but only on the nontranslocated chromosome in CA46. Using primers specific to exon 1 (nontranslocated) and exon 2 (translocated), mRNA products of the CA46 cell line can be examined independently. Thus, the ligand-mediated inhibition of c-MYC mRNA expression from exon 1 instead of exon 2 allele in CA46 cells indicates the G4 mediated downregulation. However, in RAJI cells, where both exons remain under G4 control irrespective of translocation event, there will be no exon specific effect on c-MYC expression. The dual luciferase assay (Figure 4b) is performed to investigate the downregulation of c-MYC expression by the ligand-mediated G4 stabilization.(71) In this assay, the reporter vector (Del4)(72) containing c-MYC promoter sequence upstream of firefly luciferase coding gene is cotransfected with Renilla luciferase plasmid (pRL-TK) that lacks a G-rich promoter sequence. The inhibition of luciferase expression upon ligand binding to the G4 promoter is normalized by the unchanged Renilla expression, which is insensitive to the binding of ligands with G4 DNA. Confocal microscopy is employed to visualize cellular permeabilization and localization of ligands by costaining different molecular markers. The annexin V-FITC and propidium iodide (PI)-mediated dual staining assay is performed to understand the apoptotic behavior of cells using flow cytometry (FCM). BG4, a highly specific DNA G4 binding antibody, is used to visualize G4 structures in human cells.(73)

    Advances in the Development of c-MYC G4 Ligands between 2010 and 2020

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Although a multitude of c-MYC G4 binding ligands have been known, their effects in the cellular system have not been explored in many cases. With the genome largely existing in a duplex structure, it is of utmost importance that a G4 ligand shows no or little interaction with double helical DNA. As G-quadruplexes are widespread in the genome,(15) it is important to synthesize ligands that show specificity toward c-MYC G4 over other G4s. In order to be useful for biological studies, it is desirable for the ligands to have amenable properties such as stability under physiological conditions, low toxicity, and specificity for a particular quadruplex. This would provide a good basis for a therapeutic window where the molecules interact with the target G4 structures without too many undesirable side effects.

    Effects of c-MYC G4 Ligands in Cellular Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Biophysical studies are used to establish the binding of ligands with G4s. In order to understand the functional role of quadruplexes, ligands need to be evaluated in the cellular system. Although TmPyP4 is an excellent G4 binder, it is unable to discriminate different quadruplex topologies. Progressively with time, a plethora of ligands having improved selectivity for a particular G4 DNA and prominent anticancer activities in different cell lines have been developed (Table 1, Figure 5, Figure 6).
    Table 1. Binding Characteristics of c-MYC G4 Ligands
    Sl. no.ligand nameKa value (M–1)ΔTm value and (DNA: ligand molar ratio)biophysical approaches usedbiological approaches usedref

         Cell lines used: 
         L363 (IC50 ≈ 5.8 μM), 8226 IC50 ≈ 15.9 μM), ARD IC50 ≈ 12.9 μM), JIM1 IC50 ≈ 14.1 μM), KMM1 IC50 ≈ 15.6 μM), LP1 IC50 ≈ 8.3 μM), KMS27 IC50 ≈ 9.6 μM), AMO1 IC50 ≈ 11.3 μM), KMS12PE IC50 ≈ 6.5 μM), MOLP8 IC50 ≈ 8.3 μM), CA46, KMS-11, MM-1S, MM-1R, 
    28DC-34 287.14 × 105 [SPR]7.5 °C (1:4) [CD]CD, fluorescence spectroscopy, SPR, NMR, waterLOGSYMTT assay, qRT-PCR, Western blot, cycloheximide-chase degradation assay(113)
      1.06 × 105 [fluorescence spectroscopy]    
         Cell lines used: 
         KMS12PE (IC50 ≈ 5.3 μM), JIM1 (IC50 ≈ 6.35 μM), AMO1 (IC50 ≈ 5.92 μM) KMM1 (IC50 ≈ 4.13 μM), KMS27 (IC50 ≈ 5.06 μM), ARD (IC50 ≈ 5.75 μM) OPM1 (IC50 ≈ 6.48 μM), Karpas417 (IC50 ≈ 4.8 μM), H929 (IC50 ≈ 4.89 μM), CA46 (IC50 ≈ 9.20 μM) 293T (IC50 ≈ 34 μM), human fibroblast 1634 (IC50 ≈ 19.55 μM), L363 (IC50 ≈ 3.4 μM) 
    Perylene and Coronene Derivatives
    29EMICORON 29K1 = 1.2 × 10616.4 °C (1:2.5) [FRET]ESI-MS, FRET, CD, PCR stop assay, Molecular modelingqRT-PCR, Western blot(114)
      K2 = 6.3 × 105 [ESI-MS]  Cell lines used: M14 
    Quercetin Derivatives
    30quercetin 30K1 = 0.72 × 10710.3 °C (1:2) [CD]fluorescence spectroscopy, CD, TCSPC, ITC, NMR, molecular dynamics, PCR stop assayMTT assay, confocal microscopy, semi-qRT-PCR(118)

      K1 = 1.57 × 107  HeLa (IC50 ≈ 4 μM), HEK (IC50 ≈ 0.12 mM) 
      K2 = 8.5 × 105 [ITC]    
    Berberine Derivatives
    31quinolino-benzo-[5, 6]-dihydroisoquindolium 31NA29 °C (1:10) [FRET]FRET, CD, PCR stop assay, molecular modelingMTT assay, qRT-PCR(119)
         Cell lines used: 
         HL60 (IC50 ≈ 2 μM), GLC- H460 (IC50 ≈ 13 μM), NCI-H460 IC50 > 10 μM), ECV-304 (IC50 > 100 μM) 
    Naphthylamine Derivatives
    32binaphthylamines 32a4.7 × 104 [fluorescence spectroscopy]15 °C (1:10) [FRET]FRET, UV–vis spectroscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy, NMRMTT assay, qRT-PCR, Western blot, Cell cycle analysis, apoptosis assay by FCM, confocal microscopy(122)

    Thiazole-Containing Compounds
    33TH3 334 × 106 [fluorescence spectroscopy ]22 °C (1:5) [FRET]FRET, fluorescence spectroscopy, NMRXTT assay, qRT-PCR, Western blot, dual luciferase assay, cell cycle analysis and apoptosis assay by FCM, confocal microscopy(123)

         HeLa (IC50 ≈ 3.8 μM), A549 (IC50 ≈ 3.2 μM), NKE (IC50 > 50 μM) 
    Prolinamide-Based Compounds
    34Pro4 342.8 × 105 [fluorescence spectroscopy]12.3 °C (1:5) [FRET]FRET, fluorescence spectroscopy, FID, AFMMTT assay, qRT-PCR, Western blot(125)

    Indolizinone Derivatives
    363,8a-disubstituted indolizinone 361 × 106 [fluorescence spectroscopy]NAfluorescence spectroscopy, FID, CDqRT-PCR(130)
         Cell lines used: 
         A549, HEp-2 
    Guanosine Derivatives
    37dansyl diguanosine derivative 374.8 × 107 [fluorescence spectroscopy ]12.6 °C (1:5) [FRET]fluorescence spectroscopy, FRET, NMRMTT assay, native PAGE, dual luciferase reporter gene assay, qRT–PCR(133,134)
         Cell lines used:

    Triazine Derivatives
    409CI 408.33 × 105 [fluorescence spectroscopy ]NAvirtual screening, fluorescence spectroscopy, ITC, CD, molecular dynamicsnative PAGE, cell cytotoxicity assay, confocal microscopy(137)

         U2OS (IC50 ≈ 0.845 μM)

    48BTC 48NA23.5 °C (in absence of K+)FRET, smFRET, FCS, CD, NMRNA(147)
       24 °C (in presence of K+) (1:1)   
       [FRET]   

    Macrocycles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Inspired by the pioneering study on classical G4 binder TmPyP4, macrocyclic ring systems have emerged as a promising platform to develop G4 binders.(74−76) The expanded core of macrocyclic ligands can fit well with the surface area of G-tetrad of the quadruplexes, while their steric constraints prevent them from intercalating between the base pairs of the double helix.
    In 2010, Chakraborty and Maiti developed furan-based cyclic homo-oligopeptides, 12a and 12b, for targeting the c-MYC G4 over ds DNA.(77) ITC indicated that these ligands show high affinity for the quadruplex (binding constant in the order of 107 M–1) over ds DNA. Moreover, these ligands downregulate the c-MYC transcription by about 90% in HeLa cells as evidenced by real-time PCR. They have performed the luciferase assay to validate promoter G4-driven downregulation of c-MYC oncogene. The promoter activity has been reduced to 60% by the macrocycle.
    Recently, Carvalho et al. (2018) have reported phenanthroline-based macrocycles 13a and 13b with c-MYC G4 binding properties and have evaluated their preliminary cytotoxic effects in HeLa cells.(78) The extended planar aromatic moiety of the phenanthroline enables them to π-stack on the external G-tetrads of the G4 structure, whereas the cyclic framework of macrocyclic ligands makes them specific for the G4 over ds DNA. They have shown that the binding of ligands 13a and 13b with the G4 could inhibit the natural action of Pif 1 helicase and stall the activity of DNA polymerase, leading to the genomic instability and replication arrest. However, these molecules are less toxic toward HeLa cells.

    Ellipticine Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A naturally occurring alkaloid, ellipticine, isolated from the leaves of Ochrosia elliptica,(79) has been widely used as a chemotherapeutic agent.(80) It acts as an anti-neoplastic agent by either DNA intercalation or DNA cleavage by inhibition of topoisomerase II.(81) In 2011, Hurley and coworkers reported an ellipticine analogue, 9-dimethylamino ethoxy-substituted ellipticine, GQC-05,(70)14 (obtained from NCI/DTP Open Chemical Repository, NSC338258), as a selective c-MYC G4 binder by a high-throughput FRET based melting assay. GQC-05 exhibits a maximum stabilization potential for c-MYC G4 DNA. The CD melting assay revealed a 2:1 ligand to G4 binding stoichiometry, and the SPR analysis indicated that the first site binding (Kd ≈ 0.1–0.01 μM) was 10-fold higher than the second (Kd ≈ 1.43 0.07 μM). GQC-05 is found to be 5-fold less toxic to CA46 cell line that lacks the c-MYC promoter G4 due to a translocation event compared to RAJI cell line. This indicates that GQC05 exerts a possible antiproliferative activity via stabilization of the G4 in RAJI cells. GQC05 also shows a similar trend in the activation of apoptosis cascade. It does not significantly repress the c-MYC mRNA expression in CA46 cells compared to RAJI cells. In this work, the CA46 exon specific assay (Figure 4a) was developed for the first time. This assay clearly establishes that the transcriptional regulation of the c-MYC gene is directly mediated through the stabilization of promoter G4 by small molecules and not through secondary off-target effects. GQC-05 inhibits the c-MYC mRNA expression of exon 1, while it does not show any effect on the expression of exon 2. In contrary, no exon-specific effects have been observed in RAJI cells. The ChIP assay revealed that GQC-05 decreased the binding of Sp1, CNBP, NM23-H2, and nucleolin to c-MYC G4 significantly. However, it has not altered the expression of these transcription factors, indicating that the c-MYC regulation is consistent with an effect mediated through the NHE III1 region via the stabilization of the G4 structure.

    Acridine Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Acridines are structurally analogous to anthraquinones and are known for telomerase inhibition.(82) Huang et al. in 2012 synthesized 12-N-methylated 5,6-dihydrobenzo[c]acridine derivatives for targeting the c-MYC G4.(83) In this study, the N-methylated acridine ring system was shown to exhibit higher selectivity for the c-MYC G4 in comparison to the nonmethylated counterpart. This may be due to strong electrostatic interactions of positively charged N-methyl side chains with the G4 backbone. The FRET melting assay and the SPR analysis revealed that these ligands exhibit high stabilization potential and binding affinities for the c-MYC G4. Molecular modeling studies revealed that the nearly planar crescent shaped ligand, 15 (a representative ligand), participates in stacking interactions with the G-tetrad by π-orbital overlap. Further, the qRT-PCR assay showed that these compounds downregulate the c-MYC transcription in the Ramos cell line containing NHEIII1 element but do not show any effect in the CA46 cell line lacking the NHEIII1 element.
    Recently, Carvalho et al. have shown targeted delivery of an acridine orange-based G4 ligand C816 to HeLa cancer cells through an aptamer based drug delivery system.(84,85) The ligand C8 could bind and stabilize the promoter and telomeric G4s with high affnity (Kd ≈ 10–7 M). However, it is toxic to both normal and cancer cells. In order to promote selective accumulation of C8 in cancer cells, while preventing toxicity in healthy surrounding cells, they have developed a nucleolin mediated internalization for the delivery of the C8 ligand. They have noncovalently conjugated the aptamer AS1411, a nucleolin targeting agent, and its two derivatives LNA-AS1411 and U-AS1411 containing LNA (locked nucleic acids) and uracil nucleotides, respectively, with the ligand. Biophysical techniques such as CD spectroscopy and fluorescence spectroscopy revealed that the ligand forms stable supramolecular complexes with the aptamers. In addition, the ligand could stabilize the aptamer G4 structure enhancing its nuclease resistance, nucleolin affinity, and intracellular trafficking. The MTT assay demonstrated that the complexation of the ligand with the aptamer AS1411 has decreased its cytotoxicity toward the normal cell line but remained considerably lethal to various cancer cells such as HeLa, PC-3, and A549. Further, fluorescence spectroscopic and FRET-melting assays revealed that the binding of ligand to the aptamer AS1411 did not negatively affect the recognition of the nucleolin protein by the aptamer. Moreover, the complex was efficiently taken up into the cells as indicated by confocal microscopy. qRT-PCR analysis revealed that upon treatment with the AS1411-C8 complex, the expression of c-MYC mRNA was downregulated by more than 50%. This might have been due to the transcriptional modulation induced by the interaction of C8 with c-MYC G4 upon intracellular dissociation from the AS1411–ligand complex. This study demonstrates the use of tumor-specific aptamers for the targeted delivery of G4 ligands that lack selective toxicity for cancer cells.

    Quindoline Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Natural alkaloids such as quindolines have been a popular choice for designing G4 ligands that exhibit potent bioactivity in cellular systems.(86,87) Quindoline derivatives inspired from the natural alkaloid cryptolepine(86) have been previously reported to stabilize the c-MYC G4 and suppress the c-MYC expression in the hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2.(88) In 2011, Yang and Hurley reported the NMR solution structure of a 2:1 quindoline-G4 complex using a NOE-restrained distance geometry.(13) Two quindolines 17 have been shown to bind with the parallel c-MYC G4 with one quindoline on each of the terminal tetrads. An “induced fit” binding of quindolines to the c-MYC G4 has been hypothesized based on the conformational rearrangement of the flanking sequences giving rise to a new drug binding pocket. The planar ligand stacks upon three of the four guanines in each tetrad, and the +2 and −2 flanking bases wrap over the newly formed quindoline-base planes at each end, respectively. The binding of quindoline to the G-tetrads has been assisted by electrostatic interactions between the diethylamino group in the side chain of quindoline with the DNA phosphate backbone. The binding of quindoline at the 5′-end has been more favored over the 3′-end of c-MYC at physiologically relevant K+ concentration as it is more hydrophobic and ideal for ligand stacking.
    Building over prior reports, Hurley et al. has reported a series of ligands by adding a piperazine ring to the planar quindoline ring that provided steric bulk.(89) The piperazine ring could be easily functionalized with various substituents and linkers to synthesize a series of ligands that could exhibit binding selectivity for a G4 over ds DNA. Among the ligand series, ligand 18 shows an antiproliferative effect on HCT-116 and Raji cells and considerably down-regulates the c-MYC expression in HCT-116 cells. The ligand has also been examined for its binding to various promoter G4s (HIF-1α, VEGF-A, PDGFR-β, and hTERT) and its effect on transcriptional regulation of corresponding genes in HCT-116 cell lines. It shows strong binding to both PDGFR-β and VEGF-A promoter G4s and significantly reduces the mRNA expressions of corresponding genes. However, despite inhibiting the c-MYC mRNA expression, ligand 18 does not show any exon-specific effect in the CA46 cell line. Thus, the observed cellular repression of c-MYC does not corroborate with the G4 mediated gene regulation. Thus, the anticancer activity of the ligand is due to a combinatorial effect of 7 on different genes, residing in colon and lymphoma cell lines.

    Carbazole Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The carbazole ring is present in numerous natural products and is known to display pharmacological activities such as antimicrobial, anticancer, and anti-inflammatory properties.(90,91) Therefore, the planar heteroaromatic carbazole ring system is considered as an attractive template for designing G4 ligands.(92,93)
    Huang and co-workers (2012) have reported a series of 1,8-dipyrazolcarbazole (DPC) derivatives as G4 ligands.(94) The pyrazole scaffold, known for its anticancer effects, has been incorporated to improve the overall pharmacological properties of the ligand. In the series, compound 19 exhibits less toxicity for normal human umbilical vein endothelial cell line, while showing significant antiproliferative effects in HL60, NCI-H460, and HepG2 cancer cell lines. It also exhibits an exon specific regulation of the c-MYC gene in Burkitt’s lymphoma cell lines (Ramos and CA46).
    Dash et al. has synthesized bis-triazolyl carbazoles (2015) by employing Cu(I) catalyzed azide and alkyne cycloaddition for targeting G4s.(95) One representative bis-triazolylcarbazole derivative, BTCf 20, exhibits a microenvironment-sensitive fluorescent property and is used as a nucleus imaging probe in living cells. The ligand shows a highly selective “turn-on” fluorescence response for c-MYC quadruplex over ds DNA in the presence as well as in the absence of K+ ions. It exhibits a 5-fold high binding preference for c-MYC over c-KIT1 and c-KIT2 promoter quadruplexes. NMR analysis revealed that BTCf interacts with a minor conformation of parallel c-MYC G4 and programs it to adopt a binding-competent conformation. BTCf downregulates the c-MYC expression by 75% at the mRNA level and by 80% at the protein level as evidenced by the qRT-PCR and Western Blot analysis, respectively. Additionally, it induces cell cycle arrest and promotes cancer cell death by apoptosis in HepG2 cancer cell lines.
    Later (2018), the same group developed monotriazolyl carbazole derivatives by Cu(I) catalyzed cycloaddition.(96) In the ligand series, Cz1 21 strongly interacts with c-MYC quadruplex DNA over other quadruplexes (c-KIT, KRAS, BCL2, hTELO) and ds DNA as observed by FRET and fluorescence titration experiments. Biological studies such as qRT-PCR, Western blot, and CA46 exon-specific assays indicated that Cz1 inhibits the transcription as well as the translation of c-MYC by binding to the promoter G4. The induction and stabilization of c-MYC G4 by Cz-1 in cellular system have also been established by monitoring colocalization of Cz1 with the quadruplex binding antibody BG4.
    Carbazole or benzimidazole ligands have shown significant G4 stabilization; however, instances of using benzimidazole–carbazole conjugates are rare.(97) In 2018, Muniyappa and Bhattacharya described the binding of benzimidazole-carbazole ligands to G4s present in the promoter regions of human proto-oncogenes.(98) The hydroxyethyl appendages of bis-benzimidazole 22 induce topological transformation from hybrid to stable parallel G4. It suppresses the expression of c-MYC oncogene in cancer cell lines in a dose-dependent manner.
    In 2019, Yang reported the solution structures of 1:1 and 2:1 complexes of a carbazole ligand BMVC 23 and c-MYC G4 by NMR spectroscopy.(99) BMVC is the first in vivo fluorescent probe designed to detect G4 structures in human telomeres.(100,101) It binds to c-MYC G4 with a higher binding affinity using slow-exchange rates on the NMR time scale. The detailed structural investigation revealed that the crescent-shaped BMVC undergoes conformational adjustment to perfectly match the external G-tetrad for a stacking interaction and forms a locked structure at the 5′ end by recruiting a flanking adenine (A6) into the arc of BMVC (Figure 7). Despite the binding of BMVC being weaker at the 3′ end than the 5′ end, it is more sequence-specific at the 3′ end as evident by the mutations on the flanking residues. Further, BMVC has been shown to repress the c-MYC expression at both the mRNA and protein levels in MCF-7 breast cancer cells by the qRT-PCR and Western blot studies.
    In another study, Dash et al. introduced an innovative approach of target guided synthesis (TGS)(102−104) of G4 ligands in which they employed in situ cycloaaddition using DNA as a nanotemplate.(105) Gold-coated magnetic nanoparticle-conjugated c-MYC G4 was used as a template that directs the cycloaddition of azide and carbazole-alkyne fragments to generate target selective high affinity quadruplex ligands (Figure 8). Magnetic decantation has been used to isolate the newly formed ligands. The G4 nanotemplate has been recovered and reused. These are the advantages and novelty of the TGS approach using DNA as a nanotemplate. The major lead compound Tz1, 24, shows a high stabilization potential for the c-MYC G4 as determined by the FRET-based melting assay. The fluorimetric titration revealed that Tz1, the major lead obtained by TGS, shows a higher binding affinity for the c-MYC G4 (Ka ≈ 5.9 × 106 M–1) over ds DNA. It also exhibits a 33 nm blue shift, indicating its interaction with the hydrophobic sites of c-MYC G4. The ligand inhibits c-MYC expression and induces apoptosis in HCT116 cells in a dose -dependent manner. The exon-specific qRT-PCR assay further established that the c-MYC gene is downregulated via the stabilization of G4 in the NHEIII1 element of the c-MYC promoter by the ligand. Additionally, the confocal microscopy indicates the localization of ligand in the nucleus.
    The same group used a nanotemplate-guided dynamic combinatorial chemical method(106−108) to generate specific carbazole-derived ligands for c-MYC promoter G4.(109) They employed gold-coated magnetic nanoparticle-conjugated c-MYC G4 as the template for the dynamic selection of ligands from a pool of carbazole aldehyde and amine building blocks. The lead compound, 25, exhibits selective binding to c-MYC G4 DNA over dsDNA and suppresses the expression of the c-MYC gene. Moreover, the ligand could penetrate the nuclei and induce DNA damage in cancer cells.
    These studies illustrate that carbazole derivatives can be designed as high-affinity G4 ligands with potent anticancer activities.

    Triangulenium Derivative

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In 2015, Kuimova and Vilar developed triangulenium derivatives as G4 binding agents.(110) Owing to the turn-on fluorescence property of the triangulenium derivative DAOTA-M2 26, it could be used as a probe to detect the G4 DNA in live cells by fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM).(110) Later, in 2016, Plavec and co-workers reported the solution structure of 26 with a modified 19 nucleotide c-MYC G4 (CMA).(111) The 3D NMR structure of a 1:2 CMA/ligand complex indicates π–π stacking between 5′ and 3′ guanine tetrads and triangulenium core of 26 as the major stabilizing interaction.

    Benzofuran Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Schneekloth Jr. and co-workers (2015) reported small molecule microarrays (SMMs) for the identification and characterization of c-MYC G4 ligands.(112) SMM is a high-throughput screening method for the rapid identification of new quadruplex-binding molecules. Using this approach, a benzofuran scaffold 27 was identified as a specific binder for c-MYC G4 over other nucleic acids (RNA hairpins, the FOXO binding domain, and CAG repeat DNA). SPR analysis revealed that the ligand shows binding specificity for the c-MYC over other quadruplexes such as KRAS, BCL2, VEGF, Myb, and RB1. Ligand 27 inhibits cell proliferation in multiple myeloma cell lines and suppresses the c-MYC mRNA expression in comparison to other genes. It also inhibits the c-MYC protein expression in a dose-dependent manner. Further, ligand 27 suppresses the exon-specific c-MYC mRNA expression in CA46 cells. It promotes cell death by G1 arrest and triggers a substantial increase in senescence in myeloma cells without inducing significant apoptosis.
    The same group in 2018 reported a modified benzofuran derivative DC-34, 28, by substituting the methyl group on the aryl amide of 27 with a trifluoromethyl group that selectively recognizes the c-MYC G4.(113) The CD-based thermal melting assay and SPR studies established that DC34 preferentially binds and stabilizes c-MYC G4. Fluorescence spectroscopy further revealed a higher binding efficacy of 28 for the c-MYC over DNA and RNA G4s of VEGF, KRAS, BCL2, telomeric DNA, and NRAS genes. The mechanistic basis of interaction of 28 with c-MYC G4 has been investigated using NMR spectroscopy, which revealed that benzofuran and para-trifluoromethylbenzene rings involve in π–π stacking interactions with the G-tetrads. The ligand interacts with 5′ and 3′ external tetrads of c-MYC G4 forming a 2:1 complex. Moreover, molecular modeling suggested that ligand 28 binds to c-MYC G4 DNA with more accessible short loops and flexible flanking regions in comparison to other quadruplex structures (k-RAS and BCL2). Further, in vitro cellular assays revealed that it exhibits a significant antiproliferative effect on L363 multiple myeloma cells (IC50 of 3.4 μM) and decreases the c-MYC protein levels by 50% at a concentration of 1.9 μM. Ligand 28 shows an exon -specific mRNA repression in CA46 cells. It does not alter the c-MYC protein levels in CA46 cells that lack the G4-containing promoter. Moreover, ligand 28 shows no effect on the c-MYC expression while transfecting human 293T cells in a G4 lacking CMV promoter plasmid. Further, it suppresses the c-MYC RNA levels in a time- and dose-dependent manner in comparison to other G4 driven oncogenes including BCL-2, KRAS, HIF-1α, and VEGF. It arrests cell growth at the G0–G1 phase and induces senescence at a high concentration.

    Perylene and Coronene Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Perylene and coronene derivatives are attractive scaffolds for the design of G4 interacting compounds. In 2016, Micheli et al. designed a chimeric ligand EMICORON,(114)29, by combining perylene (PPL3C)(115) and coronene (CORON)(116) and investigated the binding activity of two other ligands in the series toward G4 structures formed within the promoter regions of two important cancer-related genes, c-MYC and BCL-2. Different biophysical techniques such as ESI-MS, FRET, CD, and PCR stop assay established that all of them displayed high binding and stabilization ability to c-MYC and BCL-2 G4s. These ligands reduce the mRNA and protein levels of both the proto-oncogenes in M14 human melanoma cells. EMICORON was found to be the most potent among them. In an earlier report, the group reported the antitumoral effect of this compound in preclinical models of human colon cancer by telomere uncapping.(117) EMICORON is a promising example of a multimodal class of drugs that exerts its antitumor effects by interfering in multiple pathways.

    Quercetin and Berberine Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Flavonoids, a group of naturally occurring small molecules, have been designed for G4 recognition.(118) Biophysical assays including circular dichroism (CD), steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy, and isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) have been employed to evaluate the binding of nine representative flavonoids (luteolin, quercetin, rutin, genistein, kaempferol, puerarin, hesperidin, myricetin, and daidzein) with the c-MYC G4. Among them, quercetin 30 interacts with the c-MYC G4 with the highest affinity. NMR analysis revealed that quercetin stacks at the 5′ and 3′ G-tetrads of Pu24T G4 and stabilizes it via π–π stacking interactions without distorting the G4 structure. Furthermore, in vitro studies demonstrated antiproliferative properties of quercetin in HeLa cells and its ability to inhibit the c-MYC gene expression via the stabilization of c-MYC promoter G4.
    In another study, a series of quinolino-benzo-[5, 6]-dihydroisoquindolium compounds 31 derived from the alkaloid berberine were reported as G4 interacting compounds.(119) Although berberine derivatives were previously reported as selective G4 binders over ds DNA,(120,121) the addition of a pyridine ring and amino group into berberine has improved the binding affinity and selectivity toward the c-MYC G4. These berberine derivatives reduce the c-MYC gene transcription in the leukemia cell line HL60. These ligands show cytotoxicity on different cancer cell lines HL60, NCI-H460, and GLC-82 and are less toxic toward normal epithelial cell ECV-304.

    Naphthylamine Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In 2016, Dash and co-workers designed fluorescent binaphthylamines 32a-b, for targeting G4s.(122) The DNA-based FRET melting assay revealed that both the ligands could stabilize c-MYC G4 DNA over other quadruplexes (c-KIT1, c-KIT2, k-RAS) and ds DNA. A significant hypochromicity in the UV–vis spectrum was observed when the ligands are titrated with the c-MYC G4. In agreement with the UV–vis titration, fluorimetric titration revealed that ligand 32a containing a triazolyl side chain shows a ∼5 fold higher affinity over 32b for the c-MYC G4 DNA. NMR titration indicated that ligands interact with the 3′-end of G-tetrad possibly by restructuring the TAA-3′ capping. In vitro cellular assays in HeLa and A549 cancer cell lines revealed that these ligands exhibit significant inhibitory effects on cancer cell growth by inducing sub G1 phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. qRT-PCR and Western blot analysis demonstrated that the ligands downregulate the c-MYC expression in both mRNA and protein levels. Notably, binaphthylamines 32 exhibit a fluorescence “turn-on” response with c-MYC and are able to stain the nucleus in cells, suggesting their utility as fluorescent probes for cell imaging.

    Thiazole Polyamides

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In 2018, the same group developed a crescent-shaped thiazole peptide that preferentially stabilized the c-MYC quadruplex by site-specific interactions.(123) Thiazole tripeptide TH3 33 is structurally related to the natural product distamycin A, a potent G4 binder known for binding to the minor groove by hydrophobic interactions.(124) DNA melting analysis by FRET assay revealed higher stabilization of tripeptide TH3 toward a mutated single conformer of c-MYC (c-MYC14/23; Tm ≈ 22 °C) as well as a wild type c-MYC (Tm ≈ 21 °C) over other quadruplexes (c-KIT1, c-KIT2, and BCL-2) and ds DNA. TH3 shows a ∼4–5-fold selectivity for the c-MYC14/23G4 (Kd ≈ 0.25 μM) over other quadruplexes (Kd ≈ 1.17–1.34 μM) as observed by fluorimetric titration. The binding pattern of this planar crescent-shaped tripeptide TH3 was evaluated by NMR analysis, which suggests that two molecules of TH3 bind to the AT-rich capping regions present in the 5′ and 3′ terminal of c-MYC14/23 G4. The molecule could penetrate the nucleus of cancer cells and exhibit a potent antiproliferative activity in different cancer cell lines such as HeLa and A549, while showing negligible cytotoxicity for normal cells. qRT-PCR, Western blot, and the dual luciferase reporter assay revealed pronounced downregulation of the endogenous level of c-MYC oncogene by TH3 in HeLa cells. Moreover, FACS analysis established that tripeptide TH3 could cause cancer cell death by inducing S phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis.

    Prolinamide Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Dash and co-workers synthesized triazole-containing prolinamide derivatives for selective recognition of c-MYC G4 DNA.(125) Biophysical assays such as fluorimetric titration and the FRET melting assay indicated that ligand Pro-4 34 displays significant binding and stabilization for the c-MYC G4 over ds DNA. The in vitro cellular assays revealed that triazolyl tris-prolinamide Pro-4 shows cytotoxicity in HepG2 cancer cells and suppresses the c-MYC expression at both the transcriptional and translational level. Very recently (in 2020), the group reported that a prolinamide-derived peptidomimetic 35 containing a central pyridine dicarboxamide unit could induce synthetic lethality(126,127) in MCF 7 breast cancer cells by repressing both c-MYC and BCL2 gene expressions.(128) Extensive in vitro assays including qRT-PCR, Western blot, dual luciferase, and siRNA knock down assays indicated that ligand 35 simultaneously stabilizes c-MYC and BCL-2 G4s and inhibits the expression of the respective genes in MCF-7 cells. The synthetic lethality has been observed in other G4 ligands such as quarfloxin (CX-3543), which shows selectivity for parallel G4s, such as c-MYC(24) and VEGF.(129) Synthetic lethality could be explored as an important concept in the development of anticancer drugs.

    Indolizinone Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In 2017, Yang et al. demonstrated 3,8a-disubstituted indolizinone 36 as a G4 interacting ligand with preferential binding affinity for the c-MYC G4.(130) G4-FID assay revealed selectivity of indolizinone toward parallel intramolecular c-MYC and c-KIT G4 DNAs as compared to other G4s (BCL2, h-TELO, k-RAS, etc.) and non-G4 topologies. CD melting assay has been used to study ligand 36 mediated stabilization of the c-MYC up to a temperature of 90 °C. qRT-PCR showed that ligand 36 reduces the c-MYC oncogene expression in human lung carcinoma (A549) and human laryngeal epithelial (HepG2) cell lines.

    Nucleobase Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Nucleobase derivatives have been designed as a bioinspired approach to target G4s.(131,132) Dash and co-workers designed flexible ligands by linking a fluorescent dansyl group between two guanosine units using CuI-catalyzed 1,3-dipolar azide–alkyne cycloaddition.(133,134) The self-organization of nucleosides has been used as a strategy to interact with the G-quartet of quadruplex by stacking and hydrogen bonding. The flexible linker has been designed to tether in the groove region. A dansyl diguanosine derivative 37 exhibits a selective turn-on fluorescence response and high binding affinity for the c-MYC G4 (Kd ≈ 20.8 nM) over c-KIT1 (Kd ≈ 158.8 nM), c-KIT2 (Kd ≈ 79.4 nM,) G4 DNA as well as ds DNA (Kd ≈ 925.7 nM). NMR experiments showed the binding of ligand 37 with the 3′-end-capping structure and the groove region of c-MYC G4. It could effectively inhibit the c-MYC expression as compared to other mono- and diguanosine derivatives. The dual luciferase assay and qRT-PCR analysis revealed the quadruplex-mediated promoter deactivation by 37. Moreover, it has been used as a staining reagent in NATIVE PAGE for the selective visualization of c-MYC G4 over ds DNA.
    Subsequently, the same group has reported fluorescent guanosine anthracene conjugates, AMG and ADG 38, for targeting G4s.(135) The binding properties of these ligands have been studied using fluorimetric titrations, FRET melting, UV–vis, CD, and NMR spectroscopy. The diguanosine derivative ADG has shown excellent binding affinity toward c-MYC G4 (Kd ≈ 0.39 μM) in contrast to a monoguanosine derivative, AMG (Kd > 20 μM). The difference in the binding characteristics of two guanosine–anthracene conjugates has been studied by NMR spectroscopic studies. The presence of a flexible linker and two guanosine units in ADG facilitates the ligand to specifically interact with the capping structure, terminal G-quartets, and nearby G-rich tracts of c-MYC G4 topology. In contrast, AMG lacking the flexible linker unit exhibits only weak interactions. It has been demonstrated that ADG inhibits cellular proliferation and induces apoptosis in HeLa cells. It inhibits the c-MYC expression at both mRNA and protein levels as has been revealed by qRT-PCR and Western blot analysis. The dual-luciferase promoter assay confirmed that the inhibitory effect is due to the interaction of the ligand with the c-MYC promoter G4. Confocal microscopy showed that ADG can penetrate the cell membrane and efficiently localize in HeLa cell nuclei. It further exhibits a profound effect on c-MYC related cellular events as it suppresses the transcription and translation of hTERT and BCL2 genes in a quadruplex-independent manner leading to the inhibition of telomere elongation and activation of apoptotic cascades in cancer cells. ADG can be referred as a smart c-MYC G4 ligand that not only represses the c-MYC expression but can also modulate c-MYC related cellular pathways and inhibit cancer cell proliferation.
    Very recently, the Giustiniano and coworkers used nucleobases as synthons to prepare a library of 16 analogues and evaluated their binding efficacy toward G4 structures.(136) On the basis of CD melting assay, ligand 39 has been selected as the lead compound in terms of potency and selectivity toward BCL-2 and c-MYC G4 over other G4s and ds DNA. 1H NMR revealed that ligand 39 interacts with both the 5′ and 3′ tetrads of c-MYC while only with the 3′ tetrad of BCL2 G4 DNA. It induces selective antiproliferative activity and apoptosis in Jurkat human T lymphoblastoid cells with no toxicity toward normal cells. In addition, it represses both mRNA (∼66% for c-MYC gene and ∼67% for BCl-2 gene) and protein (∼50% for c-MYC gene and ∼40% for BCl-2 gene) expression of c-MYC and BCl-2 genes.

    Triazine Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Recently, Haider and Wei utilized G4-ligand interactions to mimic fluorescent proteins in order to locate and image functional biomolecules.(137) First, they performed virtual screening against the c-MYC Pu22 G4 and identified a commercially available fluorescent triazine 40 (9CI) containing an anthracene unit. The compound 9CI has shown a strong light-up fluorescence response for the c-MYC over other quadruplexes. This property has been utilized to construct a G4 DNA-based fluorescent probe to locate SL1 in A549 cells (Figure 9). SL1 is an aptamer that targets c-Met, a cell surface receptor for the hepatocyte growth factor in A549 cells. The construct was designed to contain two segments: a reporter strand bearing consecutive c-MYC G4s that binds to 9CI and a complementary strand with the extended aptamer (SL1-M). Confocal microscopy images showed that 9CI is capable of detecting the localization of SL1 in A549 cell periphery. In contrast, it could not detect HepG2 cells that lack SL1 membrane receptors. The detailed binding mechanism of 9CI with c-MYC G4 was analyzed by studying fluorescence responses of 9CI analogues toward c-MYC G4 DNA as well as by molecular modeling studies. 9CI displayed excellent selectivity for the c-MYC (Pu22) G4 over other G4 topologies as well as three other wild-type c-MYC G4 forming DNA oligonucleotides (Pu18, Pu24, and Pu27). The harmonious synchronization between the structural rearrangement of 3′ end loop and the systematic translocation of 9CI has been critical for such selectivity. They have shown the cooperation between the N-phenyl groups, the triazine ring, and the anthracene ring to be responsible for the strong fluorescence response of 9CI for c-MYC. Thus, 9CI stands out as an excellent example for the selective recognition and a potential candidate for biomedical imaging and clinical diagnosis.
    Randazzo and co-workers developed a series of hydrazone derivatives as topology selective G4 binders.(138) CD and FRET melting studies suggested that most of them interact with G4 structures. The monohydrazone derivative 41 stacks selectively on the planar G-tetrad surfaces of c-MYC G4 as indicated by NMR titrations. The hydrazine derivative 41 stabilizes G4 structures in live cancer cells as monitored by colocalization experiments with BG4 antibody and inhibits proliferation of human cancer cells.
    A few reported c-MYC G4 interactive ligands are discussed here which have not yet been investigated in a cellular system (Table 1, Figure 10).(139) Huang and co-workers have developed bis-aryldiketene derivatives(140)42 as c-MYC stabilizing ligands by FRET melting assay and ITC. The addition of a linker between two quinoline moieties enhanced the flexibility of ligands and improved their selectively for the c-MYC G4 topology over telomeric G4 DNA as well as ds DNA.
    Wilson et al. developed a series of pentamethine-bridged cyanine analogues 43 with various combinations of chlorine and bromine substituents on the core aromatic system as well as on the meso-carbon of the pentamethine chain.(141) The dimethyl incorporation on both indolenine rings has provided the necessary steric hindrance for the cyanine moiety to decrease duplex groove interactions, while the more polar halogen substituents enhanced quadruplex binding. The end stacking binding mode of cyanines to c-MYC has been entropically driven with a 1:1 binding ratio as has been revealed by ITC studies. The ligands exhibit weak ICD signals for the telomeric and no ICD signal for the c-MYC G4, indicating ligands bind to c-MYC with greater affinity via stacking interactions.
    Indenopyrimidine derivatives, well established for their druglike properties for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease, comprise a notable scaffold for targeting G4s.(142) Pradeepkumar and co-workers (2014) have designed and synthesized indenopyrimidine derivatives as G4 binders.(143) Molecular dynamics studies revealed that the indenopyrimidine aromatic core stacks upon two guanine bases in both the top and bottom G-quartets of c-MYC and c-KIT G4 DNA and pyrrolidine side chains, terminated with amine groups interact with the negatively charged phosphate backbone of the grooves and loops of quadruplex structures. A representative ligand InPy1 44 shows a higher binding affinity for the c-MYC (Ka ≈ 1 × 105 M–1) over the telomeric quadruplex (Ka ≈ 2.8 × 104 M–1) and ds DNA (Ka ≈ 3.6 × 104 M–1). CD titration experiments and CD melting assay showed that ligands are capable of inducing the parallel topology of c-MYC and c-KIT promoter G4 DNAs.
    The same group has subsequently reported the design and synthesis of bis-benzimidazolecarboxamide derivatives of pyridine, 1,8-naphthyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline, that specifically stabilize promoter quadruplexes having parallel topology (c-MYC and c-KIT promoter G4s) over the telomeric quadruplex and ds DNA.(144)1H NMR titration revealed that ligand 45 interacts with c-MYC G4 with a 1:1 binding stoichiometry via an end stacking binding mode. Molecular dynamics studies indicated that the specificity of ligand 45 is due to the interaction of flexible N-alkyl side chains attached to the benzimidazole-scaffold with the propeller loops of promoter quadruplexes. In addition, ligand 45 is capable of reorienting the 5′ flanking nucleotides of c-MYC G4 for favorable stacking interactions with the G-quartet.
    A water-soluble tetraazaperopyrene dye 46 having remarkably high affinity for the c-MYC G4 DNA (2 × 107 μM) has been reported by Hahn et al.(145) ITC experiments suggested that its binding affinity for the c-MYC G4 is 10-fold higher than the telomeric G4 DNA. Pradeepkumar et al. have subsequently reported benzothiazole hydrazones of furylbenzamide 47 with different side chains as potent G4 stabilizing ligands.(146) CD melting, FID assay, and Taq DNA polymerase stop assay indicated that these ligands are capable of preferentially stabilizing the parallel topology of c-MYC and c-KIT1 promoter G4s over the antiparallel topology of the h-RAS1 promoter and telomeric quadruplex and ds DNA. Molecular dynamics studies suggested that π–π stacking of the aromatic units of the molecule with the G-quartet and electrostatic interactions of the positively charged side chains play major roles in stabilizing the parallel quadruplex DNA topology. In this example, the importance of side chain modification has been highlighted to amplify the binding affinity toward a G4 structure.
    Dash and co-workers reported that carbazole derivative (BTC) 48 induces changes in the structure and dynamics of G-rich DNA sequences in the promoter region of the c-MYC oncogene.(147) smFRET and FCS analysis indicated BTC to induce unfolded ensembles of c-MYC and h-TELO G4 sequences into stable folded conformations in the absence of K+ ions. 1H NMR studies revealed that ligand 48 selectively binds to a minor conformation of c-MYC G4 and to a basket conformation of h-TELO by restructuring the loop–loop interaction in h-TELO G4.

    Organometallic Compounds

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Apart from small organic molecules, metal complexes are also known to interact with G4 targets.(148−153) Metal ion coordinated heteroaromatic scaffolds with planar geometry confer stability by aligning the metal ion with the central cationic channel of the guanine quartet. Moreover, the electron withdrawing property of the metal ion increases the overall π-stacking interaction of the ligand with the terminal tetrads. Platinum complexes have been widely used for targeting the c-MYC G4 DNA.(149−153)
    Dinuclear platinum complexes containing two dual-functional Pt cores linked by alkyl chains show specific binding toward c-MYC G4.(150) The significant thermal stability has indicated the length of alkyl linkage in Pt3 to be optimal for the two Pt-scaffolds for achieving stable interactions with c-MYC G4. Besides conventional noncovalent interactions with G4 DNA, Pt3 covalently cross-links to the 5′ and 3′ tetrad guanines thereby imparting a highly stable interaction.
    Hydrazone-derived tridentate ligands with Pd(II) and Pt(II) as metal ions have also proven to be excellent c-MYC G4 binders.(151) Cu(II) and Pt(II) bearing anthracene-terpyridine complexes have induced the formation and stabilization of c-MYC and telomeric G4 DNA.(152) Chen and co-workers have reported 5-bromo-oxoisoaporphine platinum(II) complexes to interact with c-MYC G4 and inhibit the expression of c-MYC and h-TERT genes.(153) These ligands trigger apoptosis in HepG2 cells by disrupting the mitochondrial pathway.
    However, the major limitations of metal chelated complexes are their similar planar geometry and inability to differentiate between quadruplexes.

    Effect of c-MYC G4 Ligands in in Vivo Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The global enrichment of G4 structures has been thoroughly mapped in the human genome by the next-generation sequencing.(154) Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-Seq) of G4 with antibodies specific to the interacting transcription factors indicates the involvement of G4 structures in transcriptional regulation.(154,155) Additionally, live cell imaging using fluorescent molecules has been extremely useful to locate their presence and formation in different cancer cell lines.(156,157) Despite the development of a huge number of potential G4 ligands, the question remains whether they could really be used as anticancer drugs. Considering its endogenous presence in the cellular environment and indispensible role in transcriptional regulation, it is crucial to study the effects of small molecules in in vivo systems. The first G4 binding molecule quarfloxin (CX-3543) has exhibited potent in vivo efficacy in multiple solid tumor xenograft models.(55) It has reached Phase II clinical trials for neuro-endocrine carcinomas in 2008.(158) Further development could not be continued due to its limited bioavailability.(159) The number of studies involving in vivo models (Figure 11; Table 2) is lower in comparison to in vitro reports. Hence, it is necessary to evaluate the antitumor activity of G4 binders in in vivo systems to make them useful for clinical trials.
    Table 2. Binding Characteristics of c-MYC G4 Ligands with in Vivo Activity
    Sl. no.ligandKa value (M–1)ΔTm value (DNA/ligand molar ratio)biophysical approaches usedbiological approaches usedref
